gloss.p: Draft resistance became especially prominent in the United States during the American Civil War. Both the Confederate and Union governments implemented conscription policies at different points during the conflict and included provisions deeply unpopular to non-elite Americans.

The First Conscription Act, passed by the Confederate Congress in April 1862, allowed draftees to pay for a substitute, while the Second Conscription Act, passed in September 1862, exempted enslavers who owned more than twenty enslaved persons (the so-called "Twenty Slave Law"). This second act intended to prevent slave insurrections; yet in practice it isolated rural, non-elite farmers who could not afford to pay for a substitute and were not wealthy enough to own twenty enslaved persons. (National Battlefield Trust).

In the North, Congress passed the Enrollment Act in March 1863 to conscript citizens into the military. This act, following closely on the heels of the Emancipation Proclamation of January 1863, outraged many northerners, particularly white immigrants, who viewed African Americans as economic and social competitors and refused to fight for the freedom of the enslaved. Like the Confederacy, the Union Army draft provided that draftees could purchase a substitute or commutation, but in the North, the bulk of those serving as substitutes were white men of lower socioeconomic class or immigrants. These policies produced tension among the large working class and immigrant populations of the North, leading to extreme violence, including the murder of African Americans and widespread arson in New York City in July 1863.

Up to 20 percent of draftees took measures to avoid enrolling in military service, including fleeing to the West or hiding from local provost marshals (Bill of Rights Institute). Conscription undermined nationalism and deeply affected citizens on the home front, and those individuals and their families who, based on either government's policies, viewed the prolonged Civil War as "a rich man's war but a poor man's fight" often resisted fighting for either cause.

gloss.p: In the nineteenth-century United States, the first military drafts occurred during the American Civil War, in which both the Union and Confederate governments issued conscription laws.

The Confederacy, receiving fewer enlistments than it expected at the beginning of the war, passed the First Conscription Act in April 1862, rendering all able-bodied white males between the ages of 18 and 35 eligible to be compelled into military service, but it included a provision by which a draftee could hire a substitute or obtain an exemption. Fearing insurrections by the enslaved population, the Confederacy passed a Second Conscription Act in September 1862 exempting one white enslaver for every twenty enslaved persons on a property, also known as the "Twenty Slave Law". Both the substitute and twenty slave laws isolated impoverished white southerners and rendered the draft deeply unpopular among non-elite southerners.

In the North, conscription began in July 1862 when Congress authorized the president to enlist any militia company into the United States' service. Conscription extended to the general public in March 1863 with the Enrollment Act, rendering any able-bodied white male citizen or immigrant between the ages of 20 and 45 subject to the draft. This law similarly included a provision allowing one to purchase a substitute or commutation for the then-sizeable fee of $300. Draftees could also be exempt by proving that they were the sole support of family members or other dependents.

Many individuals in the North and South saw their respective drafts as affronts to the freedom and individual liberties upon which the United States was founded, while tensions also arose between those of different races, ethnicities, religions, and social classes that were differently represented in the draft. The draft also brought home the realities of war to many families, North and South, who relied on men to support them, as fathers, husbands, sons, and brothers were sent to fight, where they would make the little money paid to soldiers and possibly lose their lives. Conscription in the American Civil War led to the violence of the New York Draft Riots of July 1863, and resulted in widespread and varied resistance in North and South (Bill of Rights Institute).

gloss.p: The Cambridge Dictionary classifies "a person who lives in the U.S. and is a member of a race of people with dark skin that originally came from Africa" as African American, but both the nineteenth-century and modern constructions are more complex (Cambridge Dictionary). Common nineteenth-century racial categories such as "mulatto" referred to persons with both white and black ancestry, and the experiences of mixed-race persons varied based on complexion, degree of African ancestry, and the region in which they lived. In antebellum cities with large populations of free Blacks, the degree of one's African ancestry could determine what rights one possessed or did not possess, and people with lighter skin tones were often considered to be white; this ended under "one drop rule" during the Jim Crow system.

Like skin tone, the ethnicity implied by the term "African American" is also problematically broad, as "naming people only by the continent of their origin and ignoring their ethnic identity is a consequence of time and space" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 5). The experience of slavery complicated the term by attempting to strip people of their original distinct African ethnic identities such as Ibo or Ndongan, classifying all persons of African descent together under one term, infusing that term with negative connotation, and disregarding the complex and rich linguistic, cultural, and ethnic histories of varied African people. However, many Black Americans have reclaimed the term "African American" and infused it with positive connotations. One scholar argues that "in using the term 'African Americans,' Black Americans accent the part of their heritage that is not American" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 4).

CWRGM — acknowledging the multiplicity of the term's meanings and connotations — includes multiracial and multiethnic people of African descent under the "African Americans" social identifiers subject tag to reflect the diversity of the African American experience and to ensure that the experiences of African Americans of mixed races and ethnicities are discoverable as they are rarely distinguished further in the letters. In the absence of other references, CWRGM also tags racial slurs targeted at African Americans — which were common in nineteenth century documents with white authors — under the "African Americans" tag. CWRGM recognizes the historic and present harm caused by such language and does not condone its use but tags these terms only to ensure the rich history of African Americans are discoverable within the collection.

Executive Chamber
Macon Miss, Dec 21st 1863.
Hon. J. W. C. Watson,

Dear Sir, As you visit Rich-mond at my request, as the agent of the State, & write to call again, by way of [?]^memoranda^ your at-tention to several matters which I have mention-ed to you in conversation.
Cotton Cards.

The Legislature has placed at my disposal $100,-000, to procure cotton and wool cards, to sup-ply the wants of the people. They cannot be procured in the Confederate States, and I cannot obtain them elsewhere except with cotton. I de-sire to send 1500 or 2000 bales of cotton through the lines for that purpose. I have propositions to procure the cards from Memphis & New Orleans, and from^in^ the latter city I have the guarrantee of ^the^ French and Belgian Consuls that the cotton will be sent to Europe only. I also desire to send other cotton for the purchase of clothing and other supplies for the State Troops and sol-diers of Mississippi, and such articles as are needed by the State.
State Troops.
By Law I am authorised to levy^raise^ such State troops as I may deem necessary. I propose that they shall act in conjunction with the

Confederate States Forces in the field, but are not to be removed from the State without my permission for a longer period than thirty days. A Sepa-rate State force will also be raised—say 2000 or 3000—to be always subject to my calls,^under my orders^ for the defense of such portions of the State, as may not be covered by the C. S. Army. I desire to know how many troops of this discription, will be paid, clothed and fed by the Confederacy , in all respects as Confederate soldiers, while under the command of C.S's Officrs in the field. The State is to pay the bounty of $50, and in the case of Cav-alry is to mount the troops. Also ascertain what arms will be furnisthed to the State troops by the Confederate States. I am informed by Ex Gov. Pet-tus and the Quartermaster General of Mississippi that a large amount of arms, camp and garrison equipage &c is due the State from the Confederate States. As the am^cc^ounts cannot be accurately es-timated^speedily adjusted^ will the Confedrate States, furnish arms and munitions, for—say 6000 or 8000 State Troops as above described. There are a great many men in the State ^in the counties^ on and near the bord^border^ liable to con-scription, who cannot be arrested by the Confed-erate States' troops. If the President will permit me to do so I will enlist them in the State for-ces for two years or send them to Conscript Camps. If the whole State was opened to this proposition I believe it would send more men

to the Army of the Confederacy, than can be obtained by Conscription. I do not believe that the C. Ss' troops, now engaged in hunting conscripts, will ever obtain as many as I could ^send^ for my troops would know them, and being interested in filling their own ranks, would compel them to volunteer in the State Troops, or arrest them. I desire at least that this privilege shall be granted in the counties on the North, South & West borders of the State, and in those contiguous to these border counties. The most rigid discipline shall be enforced, and the troops kept in the field. On the Mississippi River and especially in the Swamp counties of the State. The State Troops, knowing the country, can be made very effective for defense, and in annoying the commerce of the enemy.

I desire you to bring to the notice of the President our lately enacted statute requiring aliens to leave the State or join the C. S. Army. I do not see that any complications can arise from its en-forcement but I desire to do nothing that will in any way embarrass the Government. The law attaches no penalty to disobedence, and the aliens need not be sent out of the State, if not desired for the Army.
Civil & Military Power
Gen Pillow complains of Judge Watts and another

Circuit Court Judge for granting writs of Habeas Corpus, and returning under these writs, persons arrested as Conscripts. He contends that the State Judici-ciary has no such power, and that in the case of persons claiming exemptions on the ground of personal disability, the decision of the C. S Exam-ining Surgeons and Medical Boards, is final and conclusive, and can not be be readjudicated by a State Court or Judge. This I consider amounts to a virtual suspension of the writ, and if the Judge decides against this construction, or in any any^case^ releases the party, and the party is there detained in contempt of his decision it will lead to a conflict of author-ities. I have, however, referred this matter to the Attorney General for his opinion. I mention it here as a proper subject for conversation and conference with the Sec,y of War, who, I am informed, is of the opinion that the State Courts cannot release on a writ of Habeas Corpus, any one arrested as a con-Script. I am earnestly desirous to the full extent of my power, to sustain the Officers of the Confeder-ate States Government and to stringthin the hands of the President.

I have no complaint to make of Brig Genl Pillow, and esteem him highly as an officer and gentleman. He is doubtless administering his Dep't with zeal and ability, but you are aware of the many complaints made of

the conduct of the troops engaged in this service, and in impressments. All that are made to me I refer to the General Commanding this Military Deparment, and have assurance that they will be properly investigated, but in many cases it is dif-ficult to arrest or identify the parties quilty of violence and crime, who, in armed bands, per-ambulate the country, under authority from Con-script or impressing officers, and often doubtless without such authority. I enclose a few letters as samples of those I receive daily. Amongst them you will find a corrspondence with Genl John-ston in regard to "property confiscated," and a copy of a telegram from the Secy of War, sanc-tioning it. I do not object to burning cotton going to the enemy or within the enemy's lines, but by what authority is confiscation of horses and wagons and other property added to the penalty of the Statute, and enforced against citizens by a military ex-parte tribunal? In one case you will see that the civil remedy has been denied, and, by order of Genl Chalmers, civil processs ann-ulled. I need not inform you of the demoralizing effects of these things upon our people, or as the other and necessary^numerous^ evils attending the enforcement of thiese laws. Conscription an Impressment are necessary, but unless a wise policy is pursued

they will become odious. The act of the last Legislature in regard to illegal impressments (which I signed with reluctance) should be brought to the attention of the Secy of War, that he may consider the propriety of giving such orders as will require impressing of-ficers to comply with the requisitions of the 4th Section of that Act.

You will please to pro-cure for me copies of all the acts of Congress to the present time, and of all orders of the depart-ments in relation to the shipments of cotton, and trading with the enemy. Also copies of all the printed general orders of the War WDepartment.
Slaves Impressed at Vicksburg Pre-vious to the fall of Vicksburg.—

Previous to the fall of Vicksburg [gap] A^[a]^ number of slaves were impressed by order of Gov Pet-tus, as he informs me, on requisition of Gen'l Pemberton to work on the fortifications there. The General agreeing that the slaves should be paid for and the Confederation Government be re-sponsible for them as the State is responsible under the Statute. Compensation has not been made for the services of many of them. The parties can produce evidence of the impress-ment by order of Gov Pettus. Some of the slaves were captured by the enemy. The State is responsible for their value. Several claims

—are now pending. I ask that an officer of the C. S. be authorised to take proof of these claims and pay them, or that the commanding General of this Dep't be authorised to investi-gate the matter and give the necessary orders.

Since this mem was begun I have had very ad-vantageous offers from fully responsible parties to procure all supplies of clothing &c needed by the State, for cotton with privilege of sending it to New Orleans or Memphis. Make all inquiry you conveniently can, as to the possibility also of obtaining them elsewhere. The plan by Memphis and New Orleans is the most feasible and the cheapest, and I can see no reason why it should not be made available.

I enclose you also a paper endorsed "Agreement of purchase of Cotton of the Belgian Consul". Please see General A. G. Brown^Brown^ on this subject. I see no objection that can be made to such assales. The agents propose to pay in coin.

Very Respectfully
Your Obt Servant
Hon. J. W. C. Watson.
Copy of Memo-randa sent to Hon J W. C Watson, Dec 22nd 1863.
